I represent both government and non-government clients in relation to planning and environment matters.  My extensive experience advising state and local government authorities has given me a valuable insight into all aspects of planning and environment law and the functions and priorities of government. general.description:
Brent Lillywhite is an Environment & Planning lawyer based in Brisbane.

Brent provides strategic legal advice to developers, local governments and State government authorities on all aspects of planning and environment law.  A keen litigator, Brent’s passion lies in Planning and Environment Court appeals and declaratory proceedings.

Through the Queensland Environmental Law Association (QELA), Brent is a member of the Management Committee, Chair of the Conference Sub-Committee and member of the Seminar Sub-Committee.  Brent also sits on the Queensland Law Society's Planning and Environment Committee.  He was previously a member of the Queensland Division Committee of Consult Australia and a Committee member FutureNet Queensland (holding the position of Chair of FutureNet in 2011 and 2012).

Specialties: Brent’s areas of expertise are town planning and property development, local government advisory, infrastructure, enforcement of development approvals and conditions, resumption of land, judicial review, environmental approvals and prosecutions.

general.description:
OVERVIEW

Nicholas Andreatidis was called to the bar in 2003 after having practiced as a solicitor since 1991 as a commercial litigator, primarily in a national law firm.

He has a broad practice in commercial litigation and dispute resolution in the courts and also in commercial arbitration.  Nicholas has been listed Doyle’s Guide to the Australian Legal Profession as a ‘leading’ or ‘recommended’ junior barrister in various categories in 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

He is experienced in disputes involving contract, building and construction, professional negligence, duty of care owed by local authorities, collapses of major financial services corporations, banking and finance, franchising, equity, property, trade practices, breach of duty by directors, joint venture, partnership, shareholder and director disputes, judicial review, mining, environmental, land valuation and town planning. In addition, Nicholas is regularly instructed in regulatory enforcement matters, primarily for authorities and regulatory bodies.

He appears in all courts, arbitration and commissions of inquiry. He has extensive experience in mediation, as counsel representing a party as well as acting as mediator.


For more detail please visit:

Director at SiteFinder
Director at Viva Property Group
general.description:
James Stott has tertiary qualifications in Science, Urban Planning and Project Management, and has extensive experience within private industry, local and State government. 

James has previously worked in both public and private sector organisations and delivered a number significant projects including major high rise developments, and large master planned communities with complex environmental, planning, and infrastructure issues.

James is the Director of Viva Property Group, a Town Planning, Development Advisory, and Project Coordination consultancy.

James is also a Director of SiteFinder, a web application that provides users with detailed information about the development potential of a property, instantly.

jobs.description:
SiteFinder provides you with information about the development potential of a property, instantly. 

SiteFinder's 'Site Report'  tells you whether a land use is likely to be allowed and gives you straight forward answers about town planning and development requirements such as:
-	whether you need a development application;
-	how high you can build; 
-	subdivision requirements; and
-	risks associated with overlays or constraints.

SiteFinder's 'Reverse Search' lets you search entire suburbs or areas to find properties that match your development criteria. 

SiteFinder has a feed of active real estate listings that is updated daily, giving users the ability to search for development sites currently for sale, or off-market opportunities.

SiteFinder’s range of powerful filters gives you the ability to fully customize your search, such as highlighting properties with desirable characteristics, or removing properties that are constrained by flooding, protected vegetation and more.

Viva Property Group provides our clients with Town Planning, Development Advisory, and Project Coordination services across a broad range of developments and we are able assist with projects from site identification and due diligence through to delivery.

We provide our clients with the information and advice they need to make informed decisions, and we facilitate outcomes through a proactive and driven approach.

Our team has extensive experience within the development industry and have worked within the private sector as well as local and state government, which provides us with an expert understanding of the development and approval processes.

general.description:
Experienced Chief Executive Officer with a demonstrated history of working in the
      government administration industry. Skilled in Public Speaking, Leadership, Project

jobs.description:
As Chief Executive Officer of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority (QRA), Brendan leads Australia’s only permanent disaster recovery organisation with the vision to build the most disaster-resilient state in Australia.

Brendan oversees the efficient and effective coordination of natural disaster reconstruction efforts across Queensland with administrative responsibility for more than $14.4 billion in restoration funding under Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements (NDRRA) and State Disaster Relief Arrangements for natural disaster events occurring since 2009.

Brendan is also the Queensland State Recovery Policy and Planning Coordinator, assisting with the rapid recovery of communities impacted by natural disasters.

As General Manager (Operations) of the QRA, Brendan oversaw the delivery of the Commonwealth Government’s NDRRA program. This included managing the delivery of Queensland’s $80 million 2013 Betterment Fund, helping to improve the state’s infrastructure resilience.  He also led a multi-disciplinary team in the assessment, delivery and acquittal of more than $13 billion of reconstruction works administered by the QRA. 

A key achievement as General Manager of QRA was the development of internationally recognised damage assessment methodology used to assess damages and monitor reconstruction to housing and essential infrastructure.

As General Manager of Environment, Biodiversity and Sustainability at the Wyaralong Dam Alliance, Brendan was responsible for procurement and delivery of what was, at the time, the largest vegetation and carbon offset project in Queensland.  The project was carried out for Queensland Water Infrastructure Pty Ltd and involved construction of a roller compacted concrete dam with storage capacity of 103,000 megalitres, including a conventional concrete lined spillway and outlet works.  

The first of four new water storage initiatives on the Logan/Albert River catchment in 2010-2011, the Wyaralong Dam now provides an additional 42,000 megalitres per annum for south east Queensland.

allSkills: Leadership, Public Speaking, Project Management, Disaster resilience policy, Disaster recovery management

general.headline: Director at Philip Follent Architects Pty Ltd
general.description:
Philip Follent was one of the youngest architects elevated to the position of Fellow of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects 1989. He became State Director of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects Awards Program in 2002 and was later awarded life fellowship in August 2007 for exemplary contribution to the architectural profession. His architectural practice won over twenty architectural awards and in 1996 he was declared Lecturer of the Year at QUT across all campuses.

Philip was Gold Coast City Council’s first City Architect and was appointed Queensland Government Architect in 2008. Both roles contributed to the GCCC's and the Queensland Department of  Public Works' receiving  AIA Presidents awards for innovation in the advocacy of architecture. Philip was the inaugural chair of the Queensland Board for Urban Places and is a member of the Queensland Design Council.

In August 2010 Philip commenced his appointment as the Founding Head of the Soheil Abedian School of Architecture at Bond University. Professor Follent recently was awarded the Sustainability Students’ Association Excellence in Teaching Award. He is a Fellow of the Queensland Academy of Arts and Sciences and has recently been elected State Councillor in the Australian Institute of Architects Queensland Chapter.

jobs.description:

general.headline: QuDA Planning lawyers
general.description:
During his legal career, Andrew acted for many major Australian companies, ​as well as councils and statutory authorities, in all areas of planning and environmental law since 1996.

For about a decade, Andrew's firm acted for more developers in the Queensland Planning and Environment Court than any other law firm.

In 2005 Andrew was acknowledged by his peers in an industry survey conducted by publication Brisbane Lawyer as a 'rising star' within the planning and environment law 'club' in Queensland 

His extensive experience spanned major project and development application facilitation, due diligence on major development and industrial acquisitions and financings, and planning appeals.

This experience was gained while working for some of Australia’s largest law firms including Mallesons Stephen Jaques (now King & Wood Mallesons), Blake Dawson Waldron (now Ashurst) and Corrs Chambers Westgarth, but most recently as a Director in his own firm.

In addition to his legal qualifications, Andrew holds a Master of Urban and Regional Planning from the University of Queensland.

Andrew is a Fellow of the Urban Development Institute of Australia (UDIA).

jobs.companyName: GANTT LEGAL (formerly IPA LAW PLANNING LAWYERS)
jobs.description:
Andrew was a Director.  The firm was established in 2004.  The firm quickly built a client base.  Within 12 months, the firm was acting for more developers in the Planning and Environment Court than any other law firm.  In one year, the firm acted in 75 appeals - or about 15% of all matters filed in the Court.  Andrew and his partner Cliff Wirz, together, have acted in well over 600 planning appeals during their careers.

Besides town planning appeals, Andrew provided legal advice about approvals-based laws at the highest level of complexity, ranging from town planning, to environment, and related disciplines concerning property such as valuation, heritage and major projects.

Andrew worked at P&E Law for about 16 months.

Andrew reported to partners Lestar Manning and David Fahl, and worked closely with Cliff Wirz.

The practice focused predominantly on planning appeal work for applicants and submitters in relation to urban development proposals.

jobs.companyName: Mallesons Stephen Jaques (now King & Wood Mallesons)
jobs.description:
Andrew worked in the Brisbane and Sydney offices of Mallesons for over 3 years.

During that time Andrew reported directly to partners John Humphrey, Robert Jackson, Andrew Erikson, David O'Donnell and Andrew Beattie, and worked closely with Matthew Austin.

In the Brisbane practice group, most of the work was focused on operational and transaction advice (mergers and acquisitions and banking and finance) in the context of major infrastructure projects and facilities and major commercial/industrial urban development.  There was less focus on planning appeal work, although appeals for major clients such as Telstra and Gandel (new David Jones) featured heavily in the work involved.

In the larger Sydney practice group, the more conventional planning appeal work for both applicant and local government clients predominated.

Andrew is a proud member of the King & Wood Mallesons Alumni and continues to enjoy an excellent relationship with a number of partners of the firm.

Andrew was employed at Blake Dawson Waldron for just over 13 months.

During that time he reported to partners Paul Newman and Dr Gary Rumble, and worked closely with Peter Rowell.

The practice area was mostly focused on large energy and resources projects.

Andrew was exposed to large projects such as Milmerran, Kogan Creek, Callide and Gladstone power stations, Dalrymple Bay, Comalco Alumina Refinery, Australian Magnesium Project, either in the provision of advice in their operational roles, in due diligence roles as part of a transaction, or in the proponent or financing roles in the context of establishing a new project.

Andrew also undertook extensive work on behalf of the Commonwealth.

Andrew also undertook, but to a more limited extent, conventional urban development work and town planning appeals.

Andrew practised in the local government, planning and environment group at Corrs Chambers Westgarth for about 3 years.  

During that time he reported to partners Henry Prokuda and Ian Wright, and worked closely with Michael Leong, Matthew Austin, Robert Milne, Damian McDonnell and Michael Farrell.

It is during this time that Andrew undertook his Masters of Urban and Regional Planning for 3 years at the university of Queensland on a part-time basis, with Cliff Wirz, then of King & Company Solicitors.  His attendance was also used to sometimes lecture his fellow students on the Planning Law subject forming part of that course.

Most (but not all) of his clients were local governments, such as Gold Coast City, Logan City, Caloundra City, Redland City, and a number of others.  

Most of the work concerned planning appeals, but also advice work in areas of environment law, local government law, and so on.

Of the private client work, most work concerned large master planned communities.

There was also some exposure to infrastructure type work including energy and resources work.

Andrew is a proud member of the Corrs Chambers Westgarth Alumni.

jobs.companyName: Boyce Garrick Lawyers (now Slater & Gordon Lawyers)
jobs.description:
Andrew practised in a wide variety of legal areas during his 7 years at Boyce Garrick.  This included cottage conveyancing, leasing, private lending and securities law, personal injuries, judicial review, commercial litigation, family law, wills and estates and planning and environment law.

Andrew continues to enjoy a close relationship with the senior staff at Slater & Gordon Lawyers.

general.headline: Manager Town Planning and Urban Design at Saunders Havill Group
general.description:
I am the Manager of the Town Planning and Urban Design team at the Saunders Havill Group and have over 12 years experience both within the private and public sectors. The focus of much of my career has been on the assessment and delivery of large scale master planned developments, on both greenfield and infill sites. This has allowed me to develop an understanding of the key commerciality’s of developing large scale projects and the need to achieve balanced outcomes which meet the needs of both the private sector and government agencies.

In addition to large infill and greenfield projects, I also specialise in planning in coastal areas,  infrastructure planning and housing for the ageing. I believe these are critical planning areas within Queensland and have the potential to impact on the delivery of projects in a difficult legislative and economic environment. I believe that being able to navigate existing legislation and understand the fundamentals needed to deliver major developments, and associated infrastructure, is critical to the efficient delivery of new developments.

Beyond my project work I am passionate about the advancement of the planning and development profession and have been an active member of the PIA for over 12 years. I provide technical advice to a number of industry bodies and current sit on PIA and PCA committees.

The Saunders Havill Group Town Planning and Urban Design team is committed to achieving high quality outcomes by developing strong and lasting relationships with Clients, Local Governments and State agencies. With a key focus on development planning, the team is committed to delivering high quality town planning and urban design outcomes, for small to large-scale development proposals, and securing efficient approvals for a range of public and private sector clients.

general.headline: Partner at McCullough Robertson
general.description:
I have practised exclusively in town planning, property development, local government and environmental law since 1989 and lead a team of planning and environment lawyers at McCullough Robertson.

My expertise includes advising government and private clients on the requirements of the suite of legislation affecting those areas including the environmental  legislation at a local, state and federal level.

I provide specialist advice on major developments including master planned communities, town planning appeals, drafting planning documentation, infrastructure agreements and advising on enforcement of planning schemes, local laws and regulatory laws. 

My emphasis in recent years has been on major property development projects, and I provide solution oriented practical advice.  Environmental and regulatory enforcement are also areas of particular expertise. I have exposure to both sides of a wide range of property, planning and environmental matters spanning multiple sectors and four eras of planning legislation in Queensland.

In 2016 I was recognised by Best Lawyers as Lawyer of the Year, Land Use and Zoning - Brisbane. 

I was on the Management Committee of Queensland Environmental Law Association (QELA) from 1999 to 2012, and am a past President.

general.headline: Infrastructure and Planning Coordinator at Council of Mayors South East Queensland
general.company: Council of Mayors South East Queensland
general.description:
I’m a passionate strategic planner and project manager with over 26 years experience, and a long time supporter of projects of growth management, urban renewal, economic development,  housing supply, housing diversity, release area planning, and place making.

I’ve been following how the abovementioned key strategic planning initiatives are implemented  since the earliest days of my career spent in NSW in the late 1980s, and I am excited to see, through various evidence, various policy positions being achieved with on the ground outcomes.

In the 1980s and 1990s I expanded my knowledge by looking further afield and completing my Masters Degree in Urban Growth Management at Oxford Brooks University (UK), and also working in Halifax Municipality in Canada.

For most of my career I have worked in Brisbane and recent projects of mine are exciting, to say the least – I particularly love the integrated projects I have worked on including the revitalisation of Toondah Harbour at Redlands and the growth management challenges of the SEQ Regional Plan.

As you will see from my experience, I’ve built my career in a variety of roles in consultancy and government where I was not just a strategic planning specialist loaded with technical skills but also a manager, marketer – for new business to the planning firm, and specialist in developing networks and relationships.   I’m not only used to wearing many hats, I sincerely enjoy it; I thrive in an environment where no two work days are exactly the same.

The kind of work done at my career, I am certain, has given me a large set of research, organization and communication, analysis, legislative and statutory planning skills, as well as a strong client service ethic, which should easily translate to capably handling any busy workload.

jobs.companyName: Council of Mayors South East Queensland
jobs.description:
Support the Council of Mayors (SEQ) as a political advocacy organisation which represents the interests of those living in South East Queensland and proactively influences the Australian and Queensland Governments to ensure the long-term viability, wellbeing, and sustainability of SEQ communities.

Plan, direct and coordinate the operations of the Council of Mayors (SEQ) Infrastructure and Planning portfolio.

Improve the economic positioning of participating local and regional councils by assisting the advancement of infrastructure priorities and planning related matters within the region.

Manage the coordination and engagement in relation to the SEQ Regional Plan, the State Infrastructure Plan, State Government Planning Reform Agenda and oversee the completion of any projects funded by the State, federal and/or Local Government.

jobs.companyName: QLD Government Department of Infrastructure and Planning Regional and Precinct Planning
jobs.jobTitle: Principal Planner - Regional and Precinct Planning
jobs.description:
•	Using my 26 years experience in planning and managing large-scale regional or precinct planning  projects.

Leading delivery of the South East Queensland Regional Plan (SEQRP), and drawing on my experience in two previous regional planning frameworks.

Gathering and analysing data from agencies on land use and infrastructure.

Leading parts of the regional plan to provide a framework to implement the State Infrastructure Plan through the SEQRP - , as both the SIP and the SEQRP establish data and processes to ensure infrastructure and land-use planning are integrated, and improve service delivery.  

Working with specialists to gather data on available, unconstrained land, analyse the current or planned infrastructure, and determine a potential pattern of sequencing of land release, creating an approach where land use and infrastructure investment can be coordinated.

Inputting considerable strategic planning skills into the SEQRP. I have project managed, through establishing clear plans and timeframes, many land use Structure Plans and Master Plans. In these exercises, prioritisation and sequencing of infrastructure and land use was crucial.

Drafting the policies and actions of the SEQRP, in doing so ensuring balance and coordination of issues.

Running and working within a team environment, and leading and maintain strategic partnerships. 

Drawing on past experiences where I  have been instrumental in building "exceptional teams".

Drafting sections of the SEQ Regional Plan, and taking particular care in drafting clear messages.

jobs.jobTitle: Principal Advisor Strategic Planning: Priority Development Areas

jobs.description:
Managed town planning and environmental approval functions, overseeing a $15M capital works budget and 11-member team.

Overall responsibility for the delivery of powerline corridors ready for construction with necessary town planning approvals.

Initiation of business cases and implementation plans, forward estimating of project costs and resources, coordination of development approvals, coordinate easement acquisition, coordination of effective stakeholder engagement.

Provided linkage between local and state agencies and ENERGEX in the delivery of approvals.

Guided the Network Corridor Management Team on ENERGEX’s expectations and requirements to support ENERGEXs commitment to HSE.

Established relationships with all key stakeholders in the effective management of approvals.

Identified relevant integrated approvals frameworks including relevant legislation, policies and guidelines.

Implemented key management tools, identifying opportunities for improvement across the group for example “approvals scheduling”.

Coordinated approvals e.g.  managed impact assessment for ENERGEX under a process called Community Infrastructure Designation (CID) under the Sustainable Planning Act. (SPA).

jobs.companyName: PSA Consulting, Brisbane – Planning and engineering consultancy
jobs.description:
Developed city planning, traffic and transport planning, infrastructure, and open space environment and community planning programs for a variety of government and industry clients. Used an integrated approach to create balanced outcomes, balancing the ever demanding land use infrastructure issues with monetary constraints surrounding urban growth for clients. 

With the managing director, expanded the client base by 60% in five years by consistently delivering goal-surpassing strategic planning and environmental studies and ensuring complete client satisfaction.

Prepared, coordinated and supervised a vast array of planning studies on development applications by coordinating, motivating and leading multi-disciplinary consultant teams so that development applications were lodged, and development approval granted.

Managed the Park Ridge Structure Plan for 2400 hectares.  The challenge of retrofitting contemporary urban development over a highly fragmented area with hundreds of rural residential properties, industries, farms and community services demanded exceptional project management skills.

Delivered the Narangba Structure Plan. It required integration of all aspects from transport, energy, water and planning to the environment, communications, master-planning and project management. The structure plan will ensure coordinated infrastructure and land use delivery for this 800 hectare site. 

Managed and developed the Cleveland Centre Master Plan. The local communities’ resistance to growth required flexibility in policy development, flair and innovation, combined with professional and technical skills.. The Master Plan is now Council policy.

Developed, together with the Department of Infrastructure and Planning, a State Planning Policy for Koala Protection and a State Planning Regulatory Provision for the protection and Conservation of Koalas. This is currently being implemented throughout South East Queensland.

Oversight of major regional planning and environment documents and reports. 

Earned commendations from the Planning Institute of Australia for regional planning communication deliverables that targeted desired planning and environmental outcomes for the region and articulated these values in the SEQ Regional Plan.

Served as the Senior Regional Planner on regional research and successful policy development.

Managed the process of working collaboratively with local and state government agencies to identify their requirements for the SEQ Regional Plan.

general.headline: Barrister-at-Law
general.description:
I am Waanyi and Kalkadoon. 

I am a barrister practicing nationally. 

I specialise in large and complex matters usually involving at least one indigenous party. 

I am ranked in Chambers and Partners Asia-Pacific 2018 for my work in the native title jurisdiction. 

In 2017 I was the recipient of the National Indigenous Legal Professional of the Year Award. In 2017 I was also appointed to the Board of Legal Aid Queensland. 

In 2016 I was recognised by Chambers and Partners Asia-Pacific as one of Australia's Outstanding Young Lawyers. 

Since 2012 I have been consistently ranked by Doyle's Guide as one of the leading Native Title barristers in Australia.

In 2013 I received the Griffith University, Outstanding Arts, Education and Law, Young Alumnus of the Year Award.

In 2009 I was an associate to the late Honourable Peter Dutney in the Supreme Court of Queensland. 

In 2008 I was awarded the Griffith University’s Rubin Hurricane Carter Award for Commitment to Social Justice.

general.headline: Investor, Cosmetics - Ecommerce & Coffee Import
general.description:
After a successful career in real estate, mastering marketing and sale/negotiations I worked for several years as the acquisitions director for the Australian Property Planners Association which allowed me to develop further skills in management and project development.   Although it was coveted position and I excelled in the role, I felt as though I had reached a point in my career where I needed something which was more aligned with my natural skill set in a creative setting.  
Following my passion for cinema, photography, seeking beauty in nature, architecture and portraiture led me to found JD Productions, and since that time we have enjoyed tremendous success and delivered quality products in film and advertising to clients across a broad variety of sectors. 

We have developed an incredible team of young professionals who are passionate and highly specialized to deliver exactly what our clients expect – the best.   
Our focus is growth, meeting and exceeding expectations, and helping companies grow their business through artistic tailor made film production.

general.headline: Chief Operating Officer at Australian Centre for Robotic Vision and Superstar of STEM
general.school: University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School
general.description:
Recognised as one of Queensland's most influential people (The Courier Mail's Power100), I'm an experienced R&D leader with a focus on disruptive technologies. My expertise is in generating impact from multidisciplinary R&D programs spanning engineering, physical and social sciences. I am a trained scientist with highly developed strategic, analytical and business skills. My background in commercialisation helps me successfully bridge the gap between ideas and implementation. 

Currently I’m running the world’s first robotic vision research centre and am a board director for a mining technology company. A Graduate of the Australian Institute of Company Directors, I’m completing my MBA with UQ Business School, having gained a deep insight into public cloud adoption and cybersecurity as part of an international consulting project with the Wharton Business School (UPenn) https://gcp.wharton.upenn.edu/. 

The late George Collins described the characteristics of my brand as, "integrity, caring, genuineness, innovation and, perhaps most importantly of all, fun!" 

Recognised by RoboHub as one of 2018's 25 Women in Robotics you need to know and as a Superstar of STEM by Science & Technology Australia, I love meeting people, building connections, finding out new things and making things work better.  I'm looking to lead a technology-savvy enterprise that aligns with my personal values (integrity, people before profit) and to also contribute my advanced strategic and analytical skills to Boards.

Specialties: Strategy, leadership, disruptive technologies, governance, research commercialisation, innovation management,  negotiation,  organisational culture and branding, analytical skills, operational efficiency, public speaking, thought leadership.

jobs.description:
CRC ORE invests $35 millionto increase the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of mineral
      extraction in Australia. As a Director of CRC ORE Board as well as general advice to
      CRC ORE's executive, I Chair the Research Steering Committee, lead their Research
      Participant nominee group, and serve on the Board's Intellectual Property Committee
      and Implementation Council, looking at ways new technologies can be adopted by the
      
      Mining and METS sectors.

Leading the formation and ongoing operation of the world’s first robotic vision research centre, a $25.6m venture with more than 100 researchers at 10 research organisations spanning robotics and computer vision across the globe. Delivering the Centre’s research, education and knowledge exchange programs in the achievement of the Centre’s goal to create robots that see. 

Robotic vision will allow robots to see and understand their environment so they can work side-by-side with humans in the complex, unstructured and dynamically changing environments in which we live and work. A disruptive technology, the Centre also has a responsibility to explain the benefits and risks of the future deployment of vision-enabled robots in the world.

The Centre is hosted by Queensland University of Technology, with nodes at Monash University, The University of Adelaide and the Australian National University.

Part of a 10 person team delivering a market entry strategy for the Asia-Pacific for a multinational cyber security company interested in taking advantage of the rapid rates of public cloud adoption in the region.  To construct our strategy we spoke with hundreds of  customers and industry experts across Singapore, Japan, India, China and Australia conducting 95 indepth interviews and looked at geographic and sectoral differences in cloud readiness.

schools.schoolName: University of Pennsylvania - The Wharton School
schools.description: Working in an international team comprising students from UQ’s Exec MBA and from The Wharton School, San Francisco, we developed a market entry for a US cyber security firm looking to take advantage of the high rates of public cloud adoption in the Asia-Pacific. The Wharton Global Consulting Practicum (GCP) is a cross-functional course given within the curriculum of the University of Queensland MBA program. This is a six month program, reserved for the top 5% of The University of Queensland's MBA program.Established in 1978, this unique program pairs teams of Wharton MBA students and faculty with teams from partner universities  to consult with a client company  interested in entering or expanding its position in the U.S. or other world market. The goal of the program is two-fold: to provide exceptional learning value to the students and innovative, strategically sound, fact based, operational plans which add substantial value to clients.

general.headline: Senior Associate (Insolvency and Restructuring) at McCullough Robertson
general.description:
Ann is a Brisbane based restructuring and insolvency lawyer. 

Ann has experience in banking and debt recovery, enforcement of mortgage and other securities, insolvency and personal bankruptcy and secured and unsecured asset recovery and loss minimisation. 

In her role at McCullough Robertson, Ann advises a number of Australia’s largest retail and commercial banking and financial institutions, administrators, liquidators, receivers and corporate directors in insolvency and reconstruction matters.

Acting in both an advisory and litigious capacity, Ann acts on the enforcement and collection of secured and unsecured debts, issues statutory notices, effects possession and sales of secured assets, investigates fraud allegations as well as advising and acting on bankruptcies, administrations, receiverships and liquidations. 

Ann is a member of the Australian Restructuring and Turnaround Association (ARITA) and the Turnaround Management Association (TMA). 

Ann sits on the ARITA young professionals committee for Queensland and is also a committee member of the Queensland Law Society's Equity and Diversity Committee where she volunteers her time to work with other like minded individuals to promote equity and diversity within the Queensland legal profession.

jobs.companyName: ARITA - Australian Restructuring Insolvency & Turnaround Association
jobs.description: As part of her work on this committee Ann works to develop the needs of new entrants to the profession as well as for those who want to progress in their restructuring, insolvency or turnaround career.  Throughout the year the committee organises an exciting program of events incorporating evening seminars on both technical and soft skill topics, as well as various networking events.

general.headline: Chief, Mission Related Services at Children's Hospital Foundation
general.description:
Celia has over 10 years’ experience working in various management and leadership roles in the higher education, NFP and innovation/technology commercialisation sectors.  With significant strategy and operational experience, including general management/COO and stakeholder engagement, Celia has assisted clients in securing over $15M in funding, managed budgets up to $7M, and led teams (including finance, IT, OH&S, Marketing and administration) of up to 14 staff.  

More recent experience includes: leading change initiatives (e.g. implementing a new service delivery model and rolling out a new billing system) which has resulted in either improved service for clients or increased operational efficiency; in addition to developing strategies to address/improve diversity and inclusion (including gender equity) across the organisation. 

Celia has an MBA from The University of Queensland and has held two Board positions on Queensland based NFP Boards.  Having participated in multiple innovation challenges (for Merck and Ernst & Young) and assisted a local landscape and architecture firm in developing strategies to ensure sustainability of its operations in China, Celia has experience in developing innovative ways to achieve required outcomes/targets.

Cherish Women’s Cancer Foundation (http://cherish.org.au/) is a nationally registered not-for-profit organisation based in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia. Founded by Professor Andreas Obermair in January 2012, Cherish was established to generate funding for research and clinical trials that could be developed and implemented quickly to find kinder ways to treat women with gynaecological cancer.

The Centre for Advanced Imaging (CAI) is a world-class research and training centre, housing over 80 researchers and students, as well as 'state-of-the-art' research imaging instruments. It is the only facility of its type in Australia, and one of only a handful in the world. 

Key Responsibilities:
 - Leading and managing the operations of the Centre, including supervision of professional staff (14) and management of the operational budget (~$6.5M).  
 - Provide support to the Centre Director on strategic initiatives to increase income and raise the profile of the Centre.
 - Lead the development and implementation of marketing and business development strategies to increase usage of the Centre’s research infrastructure.

Key Achievements:
 - Attracted multiple new clients to the Centre, as well as increasing business through the formation of an informal partnership with a complementary service provider.
 - Developed and implemented the Centre’s first external newsletter (quarterly), as well as increased exposure of the Centre through social media, press-releases and tours of the facilities - including representation on Channel 10. 
 - Established a respected and professional relationship with senior executives of the university to ensure the Centre is recognised for its continued success.  
 - Led the development of a ‘Women in Imaging’ network within the Centre to provide women with career support and guidance in a predominately male-dominated field of research.

I also sit on UQ’s  SAGE Pilot of Athena Swan program committee, and Chair the Communications & Engagement Working Party.  
  - SAGE Pilot of Athena Swan is an accreditation framework for addressing and improving gender equity in universities.  As well as contributing to the development of the university's application, I am also responsible for the communication and engagement strategy across the organisation.

jobs.description:
Responsible for managing industry engagement and developing and implementing strategies to improve research outputs for Medicine (annual research income of ~$90M a year) at The University of Queensland (UQ).

Key Responsibilities:
 - Lead the development and implementation of strategies for building clinical and biomedical 
research capacity within the Faculty and the broader UQ community, to improve UQ’s global ranking.
 - Project/client manager for several ‘research centres’ operating within the university-hospital environment.

 - Identify process issues and develop methods to streamline processes in order to improve customer experience within the university setting.
 - Work with industry and hospitals (locally and internationally) to ensure appropriate contracts are in place for UQ clinicians to conduct investigator-led and sponsored clinical trials/studies.
 - Work with research lawyers and relevant UQ organisational units and local hospital and healthcare providers to streamline processes in order to improve research collaboration between Faculty researchers and local hospitals.

Key Achievements:
 - Drafted multiple business proposals to secure (>$10M) in funding from either external sources (industry) or senior executive in the university.
 - Attracted an additional $3.5M research income for the Faculty in 2015 through building mutually beneficial relationships with senior academic clinicians.

UniQuest is the technology transfer company for the University of Queensland (UQ), which is ranked in the top 100 universities worldwide, and attracts over $350M research funding annually. UniQuest's innovation portfolio includes Gardasil®, the Positive Parenting Program (Triple P), the ‘Nanopatch’ vaccine delivery technology, and Australia's largest biotech IPO QRxPharma Ltd.

Key Responsibilities:
 - Commercialisation of Intellectual Property (IP) and research contracts for the Faculty of Health Sciences at UQ (> 600 academic staff and 2,800 clinicians).
 - Negotiate complex contractual arrangements between multiple stakeholders, including large international companies, Government Departments, and Healthcare providers.
 - Business development activities, including working with clients to pitch technologies to potential investors and licensees, generate deal terms, and negotiate and close the transaction.
 - Strategy, market research, IP protection and due diligence on early-stage technologies out of the University.
 - Educate staff and students on the commercialisation process through seminars, workshops, and commercialisation experience on active projects.
 - Negotiate deal structures with investors and industry partners.

Key Achievements:
 - Worked to close a $900K investment to form a start-up company from technology developed at UQ. 
 - Conducted market research with the direct result of obtaining a higher pre-money value for a start-up.
 - Successfully negotiated a multi-million dollar strategic partnership between UQ and a mid-tier pharmaceutical company.
 - Negotiated licence agreements for UQ developed products/services, including a Telehealth software licence with Queensland Health for remote geriatric services, an online medical curriculum with a global publishing company, and a healthcare program for adults with intellectual disabilities with 4 Australian State government departments.

general.headline: Entrepreneur, investor, tech startup mentor and ‘Shark’ on #SharkTankAU on Ten
general.description:
Tech start-up investor Steve Baxter is a proud Queenslander, born in the remote town of Cloncurry and raised in Emerald in the State’s central highlands. He left school at 15 and joined the Army, enlisting in its apprenticeship program. There, he became a technician working in the field of electronics, telecoms and guided weapon systems. In 1994, at the age of 23, Steve put his life savings of $11,000 to launch his first start-up, the pioneering internet service provider SE Net, from the spare room of his Adelaide home. SE Net was eventually acquired by Ozemail/UUNet under the stewardship of its founding Director and now Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull.

In 2001, Steve and a schoolmate launched his second start-up, PIPE Networks, a provider of wholesale telecoms infrastructure that listed on the ASX in 2005. Eight years later TPG Group acquired it for $373m. Steve spent a year with Google in California in 2008, leading a project to deliver high-speed telecommunications systems across North America.

Since 2010 he has become a major early stage investor in startups leading to the founding of Brisbane tech startup hub River City Labs, founded and underwrote the Startup Catalyst and River Pitch programs; he has been on the listed boards of Vocus Telecoms, Indoor Skydive Australia Group and OtherLevels as well as on the board of Commercialisation Australia. He has been heavily involved in the early days or founding of numerous industry groups and forums, including the South Australian Internet Association, South Australian Internet Exchange, Australian Domain Name Authority, AuDA, INTIAA, IIA, AusBone and AusNOG.

He has been a Shark on Channel 10’s Shark Tank Australia for the past three seasons. In 2006 Steve received the Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year for the Northern Region. In 2016, he received the Pearcey Medal for Lifetime Achievement in recognition of distinguished lifetime achievement and contribution to the development and growth of the ICT industry.

Ryan has over 12 years’ experience in information technology and related practices, with the last 8 years focussed on enterprise digital risk and cyber security. These programmes have included proportionate blends of people, processes and technologies, aligned to industry better practice to meet customer, compliance, regulatory and business objectives.

Ryan has led and managed a successful security services business in Queensland for several years, helping clients improve their capability maturity by leveraging a team of experts that cover the full spectrum of digital risk and cyber security services. general.headline: Archaeologist, lithic artefact specialist at Navin Officer Heritage Consultants
general.description:
I have worked as an archaeological consultant for fifteen years, most recently as a full-time employee for Huonbrook Environment and Heritage (Philip Hughes and Marjorie Sullivan, directors) from 2010-2013, and Navin Officer Heritage Consultants (Kerry Navin and Kelvin Officer, directors) from 2013 - present.  I have worked on all stages of the process of carrying out archaeological projects, with a focus on lithic data analysis and field project management.
Since 2003 I have worked as a sessional lecturer and tutor at the Australian National University, teaching undergraduate and postgraduate students on archaeological field and laboratory methods, research design and statistical analysis.  In 2010 I developed a week-long intensive course on the analysis of lithic artefacts, and ran this course annually for Masters students in ANU's Masters of Archaeological Science program.
My main interests are the analysis of lithic assemblages, and statistical analysis of archaeological data.  I am currently also interested in photography of archaeological specimens, sampling strategies employed in archaeological field project design, and the effect of taphonomic processes on archaeological assemblages.

allSkills: Research, Teaching, Project Management, Lecturing, Lithic analysis, Field archaeology, Data analysis and visualisation, Photography of artefacts

jobs.description:
Tim Longwill is a senior legal practitioner and partner at McCullough Robertson lawyers. He has been a practising lawyer for over 20 years and, for the last 10 years, has specialised in advising health and aged care providers in the government, private and nonprofit sectors.

His practice has involved providing strategic and operational advice on all aspects of the aged care industry including legislative compliance, human resources and business drivers. 

Tim has been a vocal advocate for the appropriate provision of quality aged care in Australia and, through Tim’s involvement,  McCullough Robertson has been a supporter of Aged Care Queensland’s ‘Excellence in Care Awards’ for a number of years and maintains a close association with the sector and its peak body. 

Tim has acted in most of the Aged Care sector’s landmark industrial relations and compliance decisions in the last 10 years and provides regular commentary for national newspapers and magazines on issues influencing the sector.

Tim has acted on behalf of the Queensland Government in its arbitration of the Federal Public Sector Award and the arbitration of the Queensland Ambulance Services
Determination and recently the Queensland Health pay dispute.

Highlights of Tim’s experience include:

• acting on behalf of Queensland aged care
providers in the first low paid authorisation case
before Fair Work Australia

negotiations for award amendments, and

disputes involving enterprise bargaining,
redundancy and significant change of hours.

Tim has been a guest lecturer with the University of Queensland and Queensland University of Technology’s Business School of Philanthropy and Nonprofit studies.

Tim holds a Master’s degree in law and has been a member of the Queensland Law Society’s Elder Law Committee for 10 years.

general.headline: KPMG Food & Agribusiness | NED | MBA | GAICD
general.description:
Georgie is a personable & dynamic individual with demonstrated success at both a senior executive & NED level within the agribusiness & food sectors. She has vast strategic planning experience; executive management & board experience; sound corporate governance knowledge; strong interpersonal & communication skills coupled with an extensive food & agribusiness network. 

Throughout her career to date, Georgie has governed & led the delivery of several organisational restructure & transformation projects through sound strategic thinking & planning; delivered significant industry & Government funded projects & initiatives, with experience managing not-for-profit to multi-million dollar businesses & business unit portfolios. 

Georgie  maintains a strong personal interest in the ongoing evolution of corporate governance in Australia & currently serves as a Non-Executive Director of Pulse Australia Ltd, Agribusiness Australia Ltd & Workforce Consulting Pty Ltd. 

Georgie was awarded the Inaugural Rabobank Emerging Agribusiness Leader Award in 2013 – a peer nominated & judged award for an up-and-coming leader with less than 10 years’ ANZ food & agri industry tenure. The Australian Financial Review named her as one of Australia’s 100 Women of Influence in 2014 & in the same year, Fairfax Media & the Emerald Group listed her in the Inaugural 100 Women in Australian Agribusiness.

Georgie is both a Member & Graduate of AICD with a Bachelor of Business Management (Equine) from The University of Sydney & MBA from Macquarie Graduate School of Management (MGSM). 

Georgie's specialties:
* NED & Senior Management
* Strategy
* Stakeholder Engagement
* Agribusiness/FMCG
* NFP

jobs.description:
KPMG’s Food and Agribusiness group offers audit, tax and advisory services geared to
      the unique needs of the sector. Clients draw on our deep industry experience and
      extensive technical resources to augment their internal capabilities and to obtain a
      fresh, independent perspective on important strategic and operational issues. In her
      current role, Georgie works within the KPMG Food and Agribusiness Management
      
      Consulting team.

Providing consulting services on a range of agribusiness/food projects following some professional and personal travel overseas.

Open to exploring and discussing consulting opportunities with interested companies. To discuss, please send LinkedIn message or email georgiealey@gmail.com.

Workforce Consulting is an organisational and HR consultancy working with small and medium businesses across all industry sectors to develop and implement a complete range of HR structures and systems to address existing deficiencies or to create required solutions. The company specialises in organisational restructuring, HR audits and HR management systems such as Performance and Succession Management, as well as leadership and management training and coaching.

Agribusiness Australia Limited is the only national membership network for
      agribusiness, advancing and advocating the interests of the sector. Georgie is currently
      
      Chair of the Events Committee.

Georgie was appointed to the Pulse Australia Board in December 2013 and to the position of Vice Chair in October 2016. Pulse Australia is the peak industry body that represents all sectors of the Australian pulse industry, providing coordinated leadership and facilitating a range of activities across trade and market access, receival standards and agronomic support that achieve improved profitability for all sectors of the industry.

jobs.companyName: The Australian Institute of Food Science and Technology
jobs.description: The Australian Institute of Food Science and Technology Ltd. (AIFST Ltd) is the only national independent voice and network for Australia's food industry professionals that underpins and supports their contribution to the Australian and global food industry. AIFST's vision is to advance Australia's position as a sustainable, world-leading food industry. Georgie was appointed as the inaugural CEO in April 2015 to lead and manage the governance and operational transition of the organisation from its prior Incorporated Association structure to a Company Limited by Guarantee. During her time at AIFST, Georgie led significant transformational change both at a strategic and operational level within the organisation to reposition the Institute as a modern, relevant and sustainable organisation.

The Grains & Legumes Nutrition Council (GLNC) is the independent authority on the nutrition and health benefits of grains and legumes. GLNC's contributor base represents Australian grain producers and 60% of the grain and legume food manufacturing industry. As Managing Director and Company Secretary, Georgie led the development and delivery of the 2014 – 2016 Strategic Plan. The Plan delivered significant results including increasing GLNC’s consumer audience media reach from FY13: 2.75 million to FY16: 44 million and social media growth from FY13: 295 to FY16: 47,000. In addition, she implemented several new procedures and systems within the company including the Risk Management Strategy and governance compliance including ASIC reporting, WH&S and HR. Under Georgie’s leadership GLNC’s member Net Promoter Score (NPS) increased from -25 to +35.

jobs.jobTitle: Non Executive Director, Chair & Company Secretary
jobs.description:
Georgie was appointed as a Director in November 2008 to the Future Farmers Network (FFN) - the only national youth agricultural organisation in Australia. Launched in 2002 as a national not-for-profit organisation and incorporated company limited by guarantee. Today FFN represents thousands of members across Australia by taking a national leadership role in advocating, educating and providing support to young people working in Australian agriculture.

Georgie was appointed Chair of FFN from December 2010 to November 2015. Under Georgie's leadership FFN grew to become the preeminent organisation supporting the future of Australian agriculture. Georgie secured over a million dollars worth of industry funding to support the organisations objectives and built FFN's key strategic industry relationships.

As well as maintaining her role as Director and member of the Board's Communications Committee, Georgie was appointed Company Secretary in November 2009 and a member of the Board's Corporate Governance Committee.

Reporting directly to Chief Executive Officer and a member of Senior Management Team, in her more recent roles Georgie was responsible for GrainGrowers policy and corporate affairs/communications portfolios as well as having held responsibility for driving the commercial revenue for the Technical, Analytical and Information Services divisions within GrainGrowers'. In her various roles Georgie liaised directly with producers, State and Federal Ministers, Government Departments, producer and industry representative groups and research organisations. 

Achievements in these roles included:

jobs.description:
The Grains Research and Development Corporation is a statutory authority established to plan and invest in research, development and extension (RD&E) for the Australian grains industry. 
Its primary objective is to drive the discovery, development and delivery of world-class innovation to enhance the productivity, profitability and sustainability of Australian grain growers and benefit the industry and the wider community. 
Its primary business activity is the allocation and management of investment in grains RD&E.

In 2015 the GRDC invested approximately $200 million in innovation for the benefit of Australian grain growers.

Australian Crop Accreditation System (ACAS) Limited manages National Variety Trials (NVT), a national program of comparative crop variety testing with standardised trial management, data generation, collection and dissemination. The program is supported by the Australian Government and growers through the Grains Research and Development Corporation.

Key responsibilities:
As a member of the GRDC Executive, shared accountability for setting the strategic direction, policy framework and business objectives of the GRDC.

Primary accountability for managing all aspects of the GRDC’s R&D investment in the ‘better varieties faster’ pathway including gene discovery, germplasm development, breeding, National Variety Trials, and variety commercialisation across the 25 levied crops.

Primary accountability for an R&D budget of about $51M per annum, and a national portfolio of about 200 projects with 40 different R&D organisations.

general.headline: Founder/MD, Farm Table (farmtable.com.au)
general.description:
Airlie is the Founding and Managing Director of The Farm Table — www.farmtable.com.au —  an online ecosystem designed to support, educate and motivate this and the next generation of Australian farmers.

The new look Farm Table is all about harnessing the collective know-how of the Australian ag industry for farmers by creating an ecosystem for two-way collaboration. The Farm Table will be interactive and customised for each farmer, adding real value to our visitors throughout their learning journey, growing with them as they do.

Before turning her attention fulltime to The Farm Table, Airlie was a Business Analyst with Macquarie Bank’s Paraway Pastoral Company, one of the largest pastoral land owners and operators in Australia, with a total combined land holding of over 4.4m hectares. 

Prior to this, Airlie worked fulltime on her family’s mixed livestock property in Holbrook, NSW, where she grew up and her family have been farming for over three generations. 

Before returning home, Airlie completed her Masters in Food and Resource Economics at the University of British Columbia. Airlie took a leave of absence from her consulting career with PricewaterhouseCoopers in Melbourne to move to Canada to further develop her capabilities and skills with the long-term aim of working fulltime in a career dedicated to the agricultural industry.

Airlie is currently a member of Industry Advisory Group for the Government’s Farm Cooperatives and Collaboration Pilot Program. She was also named a 2016 “Tomorrow Maker” by the AMP Foundation, spoke at the 2016 AgriVictoria Conference, was a 2015 RAS NSW Rural Young Achiever and 2015 Woolworths Agribusiness Scholar. 

Airlie is currently living with her partner on his mixed farming enterprise in Deniliquin, NSW. She was recently asked to present a keynote address at the 2017 Australia Women’s Leadership Symposium in Canberra.

jobs.description:
***The Farm Table is relaunching in 2017***

The Farm Table is approximately two years old. It originally began while Airlie was at home on her family farm trying to upskill and learn as much as possible to make a difference in her family farming business.

To date, it has been a DIY site and a hobby venture aimed at building up market research and experience. Airlie is now wholly committed to redeveloping and rebuilding a professional, valuable and much-needed offering in the agricultural space.

Will the new site be different? Yes, but the key problem The Farm Table is trying to overcome remains the same  - a growing frustration of knowing there is so much knowledge in the agricultural industry but it takes so much time to be find it, capture it, make sense of it and then garner some practical learnings from it.

New farmers are hungry for knowledge and opportunities, however there is no central platform to access resources, training opportunities, peer and mentor exchange opportunities. The redeveloped site will be more focused, timely and have a much-improved user experience. The Farm Table will continue to harness the industry's knowledge, but in a way never seen before.

The Farm Table online ecosystem will harness the collective know-how of Australian Agriculture for farmers by creating an online platform for two-way collaboration and learning.

The goal is to become farmer’s trusted online sidekick to enable them to connect with others, continuously learn and grow in their confidence in order to improve their farm businesses.The Farm Table is a central, online information toolbox focused on linking the agricultural sub-industries through information dissemination.

jobs.description:
Robbie has led Seftons to become one of Australia’s leading strategic communications consultancies, under the guiding vision of contributing to a healthy and innovative agricultural, rural and regional sector. 

She has successfully managed large and complex projects and campaigns that contributed substantially to Australia's agriculture and land use sectors, including Australia’s Farming Future, the Agricultural Competitiveness White Paper, the National Biodiversity Strategy, Water for the Future, and the Murray Darling Basin Plan. Seftons was winner of 2013 Government Relations Consultancy of the Year award.

Seftons has a strong portfolio of blue chip clients including: 

CORPORATES: Westpac Agribusiness, Woolworths, Case IH, Bayer Animal Health.

GOVERNMENT: Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Department of Agriculture and Water Resources, NSW Department of Education, NSW Department of Industry, NSW Department of Primary Industries, Environment Australia, National Carp Control Program, National Biodiversity Strategy Review Task Group, Local Land Services.

SEMI-GOVERNMENT: Meat and Livestock Australia, Hort Innovation, Rural Industries Research & Development Corporation, Fisheries Research & Development Corporation, Australian Meat Processor Corporation, Australian Maritime Safety Authority, Murray Darling Basin Authority.

NOT FOR PROFIT/OTHER: Country Women’s Association NSW, National Farmers’ Federation,  Australian Rail Track Corporation Inland Rail, Southern Phone Company.

On 30 April 2018, Senator the Hon Bridget McKenzie, Minister for Regional Communications, announced the commencement of the 2018 Regional Telecommunications Review. Robbie Sefton has been appointed as one of the six advisory committee members, joining chair Sean Edwards, and members Wendy Duncan, Johanna Plante, Kylie Stretton and Paul Weller. The committee will review telecommunications services in regional, rural and remote parts of Australia, and will consult directly with affected individuals and communities.

Robbie has been appointed the recently formed CRC-HPS, as board member and member of the audit and finance sub committee. The CRC-HPS started operations in June 2017 with $39.5 million from the Government to establish a ten-year global program. It will bring together 42 partners spanning industry, government, research, not for profit and business sectors to help bridge the gap between soil science and farm management. The investment from government will be supported by more than $136 million in contributions from industry and other partners (cash and in-kind) over ten years.

The National Australia Day Council (NADC) is a not-for-profit government-owned social enterprise within the Prime Minister’s portfolio responsible for coordinating Australia Day celebrations and the Australian of the Year Awards. NADC heads a network of eight state and territory organisations and 789 local committees. Robbie's appointment to the board was made by the Prime Minister.

Robbie has sat on the NSW state selection panel for Australian of the Year four times, three times in the capacity of chair. As Deputy Chair of the National Australia Day Council she has been a national representative on selection panels in NSW, SA and TAS. She is the Chair of Future Strategy Sub Committee for NADC.

She has over a decade’s involvement with state and national Australia Day Council boards which has seen the achievement of her vision to recognise ordinary Australians doing extraordinary and inspiring things in the Australian of the Year Awards.

With over 36,000 shareholders, Graziers’ Investment Company Limited (GIC) was previously known as Australian Wool Services Limited (AWS). Robbie was one of five directors and was re-elected three times by shareholders with a vote of over 97% each time. When Robbie joined the board the company had a debt of over $80m and complex inherited legacies. During her tenure, the organisation retained the iconic 'Woolmark' certification trademark in the hands of Australian woolgrowers, improved shareholder value and preserved shareholder wealth whilst satisfactorily resolving past issues.  When she left the board, GIC was a company with net assets of $20m and share value of $9.55.

Australian owned agri specialist bank, supporting Australian farmers and rural
      
      communities.

Agriculture in Australia is a vital component of the national economy, but faces growing challenges on a broad range of fronts as the population becomes highly urbanised and remote from the realities of farm business. In order to ensure the needs of agriculture are well understood and appropriately considered in policy decisions made by governments, it is becoming increasingly important for farmers to adopt a strategic approach, and to establish policy agendas, rather than just respond to them.
The Australian Farm Institute has been created to carry out this strategic role on behalf of Australian farmers.  The Institute’s founders recognised that in order to successfully develop and promote policies that will benefit farmers, it is essential that those policies are soundly based, and are supported by rigorous and objective research.

The Prime Minister’s Community Business Partnership (the Partnership) has been re-established to promote a culture of giving and volunteering in Australia. The National Rural Advisory Council (NRAC) is a skills–based independent advisory council to the Australian Government Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

NRAC was established in December 1999 as a statutory consultative body following legislative changes to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992. It replaced the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council and expanded the range of roles and functions of the original council.

NRAC advises the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on matters such as rural adjustment, regional issues, training, exceptional circumstances (EC) applications and extensions to EC declarations and other matters as requested by the Minister.

The Kimberley Pilbara Cattleman’s Association was officially launched in April 2015. The main aim of the KCA is to protect, promote and develop the Kimberley and Pilbara Pastoral industries while creating a prosperous, innovative, sustainable and resilient pastoral industry. 

My role within the KCA is to build a collaborative Association that truly represents the interests of pastoralists and other key stakeholders along the supply chain. The Association will grow through increasing membership, establishing key corporate partners, developing key industry programs and being innovative in our collaborative approaches to research, development, extension, monitoring and evaluation.

We aim to maximise the potential of the northern beef industry through effective partnerships, clear and transparent communication and connecting those along the value chain.

jobs.jobTitle: Indonesian Australian Partnership on Food Security in the Red Meat and Cattle Sector
jobs.description:
This partnership is the first ever bi-partisan, public private sector agreement between Australia and Indonesia. The members were appointed by the Minister the Hon. Barnaby Joyce and approved by PM Hon Tony Abbott. On this partnership there are independent partners and government representatives from both Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Together, we are working with Indonesian Government representatives and independent Indonesian Partners to develop long term sustainability in the Indonesian red meat and cattle sector. This is a $60 Million project to be rolled out over 10 years.

Skills include  
Strategic development
Technical project development and analysis
Networking with key stakeholders

Influential Women is a company I founded after recieving the WA RIRDC Rural Women's Award in 2012. The vision for Influential Women is to create connections between Rural Women across cultures and generations to promote growth, viability and well being.

My role in Influential Women has been the Founder and Managing Director, 

My key roles have been in presenting, facilitating, strategy, marketing, social media and stakeholder engagement. The areas that I have specialised in are;


•	Effective and engaging use of language
•	How to handle and stay safe in difficult conversations 
•	Using the media and social media to get your messages across
•	Public speaking coaching
•	Goal setting
•	International farming tours and leadership development programs across cultures
 
Nothing gives me more pleasure than working with people, fostering them become what ever it is they want to be. If I am able to light a fire in people that attend a conference or a workshop, then rural Australia will remain a wonderful place to live. The power is in the people of a community, when people are empowered and inspired, communities thrive, no matter where you are on this wonderful planet of ours.

During my time working as a technical consultant in the Asian Beef Industry, I worked for a number of clients including Meat and Livestock Australia, the Department of Agriculture and Food WA and Wellard Rural Exports. All companies were very rewarding to work with as I was able to contribute to the success of the industry on the ground in our own back yard as well as receiving countries, mostly Indonesia and the Philippines.

I worked in areas of ruminant nutrition, feeding management, feedlot management, supply chain assurance, animal handling and in the development of breeding programs. 

My time working in the Asian beef industry was very rewarding on three levels, 1) I was able to constantly improve animal welfare and production potential of animals in our overseas markets, 2) I was able to improve workplace health and safety of people on the ground in receiving countries by educating on how to feed/handling cattle and 3) I was able to contribute to the northern beef industry by ensuring we have a market that is viable and sustainable into the future (politics aside of course)

Nothing gives me more pleasure than working in areas where I can make a real difference. Working on the ground, with farmers in Indonesia and the Philippines was such a rewarding and unforgettable experience. Seeing the joy on farmers faces when you can show them how to make their job easier is such a gift. I think I learnt as much from the people I met as what I was able to give to them

In this position I was in charge of formulating feedlot rations for clients as well as
      premix formulations to balance out those rations. BEC Feed Solutions is a premixing
      plant so I had the ability to formulate specific mineral and vitamin requirements for
      
      specific clients which was determined by what they were feeding and how.

I was involved in liaising with pastoralists to determine their production goals, their
      pasture quality and their management structures and formulating loose mix mineral
      
      supplements to help pastoralists achieve their production goals.

general.headline: Owner at Carbon Farmers of Australia
general.description:
I am passionate about agriculture and the role agriculture can play in drawing down CO2 from the air, to prevent the worst effects of climate change and improve the productivity of farming land.  I am particularly focused on the role of soil carbon for improved water holding capacity and soil structure. 

We are working in Australia with the Government's Direct Action Policy - which has several methodologies available for the Land Sector to participate. We have a concept of a whole-of-farm carbon audit to enable farmers to choose which 'methods' are applicable to their farm - both emissions reductions and sequestration. Farmers can earn Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCU's) for their efforts and can bid into the Emissions Reduction Fund to be paid for their efforts. 

These methods, once established and proven, can be taken overseas to help poor farmers to do the same and be paid by the big polluters. That is my ultimate goal.

jobs.description:
We formed Carbon Farmers of Australia  to ensure that farmers would be able to trade
      in the new carbon markets, and to be paid a fair price in that trade.  We have a passion
      for soils, and look forward to the day that soil carbon is traded in this market as well, 
      under the Carbon Farming Initiative - because it is the largest carbon sink over which
      we have control, and as you return carbon to the soils you improve its water holding
      
      capacity and structure. A win/win for farmers and for climate change mitigation.

We set up the Carbon Farming and Trading Association to protect farmers rights within
      
      the carbon trade.

Direct Marketing agency and call centre.   Not sure if it still exists. 
We  established it with one other director from the kitchen table to over 50 employees.  
We have since moved to the country and are now directors of Carbon Farmers of Australia -  assisting farmers to trade in the new carbon trading opportunities,  and build climate resilience into their farming systems.

I am the Chief Executive Officer of the Red Meat Advisory Council, the supply chain advocacy and advisory organisation for Australia's 82, 000 red meat producers, lot feeders, manufacturers, retailers and exporters.  

We work with many to grow the value and reputation of Australia's $18-billion-dollar industry as a supply chain, or from "paddock to plate." 

Our focus is on organisational credibility through world-class governance and government relations by promoting the important economic and social role of our industry to Australia's consumers, community and families. Employing 405, 000 Australians directly and indirectly and contributing $15-billion in export earnings!

jobs.description:

This includes all aspects of company financial and operational delivery; and being the public figure of RMAC to the agribusiness community, Australia's three levels of government and our international diplomats. 

Key accomplishments including establishing a series of Red Meat Roundtables (intimate events connecting decision makers directly with the business community), launch the first ever Red Meat State of the Industry 2017 report, hosting the inaugural Red Meat Nation party at Australian Parliament house, co-collaborating on the Australian Beef Sustainability Framework and spearheading multiple supply chain policy platforms in areas of trade, transport and efficiency. 

Drive an overall organisational emphasis on industry credibility and accountability as Company Secretary and excellence in company administration.

Drive policy reform agenda for profitability for Queensland beef producers - Queensland's largest agricultural commodity.

general.headline: Infrastructure and major resources projects lawyer
general.description:
I am a infrastructure, major resources and energy lawyer based in Brisbane with an interest in public policy - particularly in relation to energy and public infrastructure. 

My general practice consists of largely contentious construction and infrastructure, oil and gas, and renewable energy matters, where I assist both principals and contractors in resolving disputes through litigious and non-litigious means.  I also practice in, and have significant experience in non-contentious construction and major projects work (both private practice and secondments), and the drafting of various bespoke and Australian Standard form construction and services contracts for clients in the renewable energy, oil and gas, mining and resources, health care, and sporting and leisure sectors.

Prior to full time private practice, I was a Judge’s Associate to his Honour Judge Michael Noud of the District Court of Queensland, and to Deputy President the Hon. Leslie Kaufman of the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission.

jobs.description:
Board Connect is a non-profit organisation that provides services designed to support the boards of other non-profit organisations in Australia.  

Board Connect's services have been developed in response to non-profit boards’ ongoing need for advice, support and skills development.  Initially focused on the needs of arts and cultural organisations, services now extend both into the broader non-profit sector and around Australia.  

Board Connect works to strengthen non-profit boards and committees of management of community organisations, to ensure they understand their responsibilities as board members, and govern their organisations for the best outcomes.

general.headline: Corporate & Commercial Lawyer specialising in M&A Corporate Governance and Competition Law | Partner at Piper Alderman
general.description:
I am a corporate and commercial lawyer based in Brisbane with over 20 years post-qualification experience. I regularly work with domestic and international clients on M&A transactions. capital raisings, competition law and Australian regulatory compliance matters. I advise both private companies and publicly listed companies and have particularly strong experience in acting for those in the financial services, healthcare, aged care and agribusiness sectors.

I was nominated by my peers for inclusion again in the 2017 Edition of Best Lawyers in Australia in the practice areas of: Mergers and Acquisitions Law, Corporate Law, Corporate Governance Practice and Competition Law.

My clients tell me that they appreciate my technical legal skills and the commercial manner in which I apply those skills to their matters.

jobs.description:
Andrew is a partner in our Brisbane office. He is an experienced corporate and commercial lawyer with more than 20 years’ experience.  Andrew regularly works with domestic and international clients on mergers & acquisitions, capital raisings, competition law and Australian regulatory compliance matters.

Andrew advises both private companies and publicly listed companies and has particularly strong experience in acting for those in the financial services, healthcare, aged care and agribusiness sectors.
Prior to joining Piper Alderman, Andrew spent more than 10 years as a partner with an international firm in Brisbane in the corporate team. 

Andrew was named in the 2017 edition of Best Lawyers® Australia in the practice areas of: Mergers and Acquisitions Law, Corporate Law, Corporate Governance Practice and Competition Law.

Andrew is responsible for driving growth for the Brisbane M&A/Corporate team. He has
      a particular focus on the financial services, health, aged care and agribusiness sectors.
      
       HIs clients include Fresenius-Kabi, QXR and Eve Health.

Andrew was appointed local area manager for Brisbane Corporate. He has a particular
